comments:
In Eclipse 3.3, if I have TOC file declared in my plugin.xml but that file doesn't exist, it results in an error with a stack trace in the product's log file.

A warning would be adequate.

Also, if I am missing a label on the TOC element in a TOC file, I get a stack trace in the log. An error listing the file that is missing label is adequate for this.

Including the debug info when it isn't necessary pollutes the log file.

I think the stack trace is useful, in the case of the missing file the first lines in the log are

java.io.FileNotFoundException
at org.eclipse.help.internal.toc.TocFileParser.parse(TocFileParser.java:45) - which makes it easy to track down the problem.

If we just reported the message:

Error reading help table of contents file /"com.cg.hwarn/toc2.xml" (skipping file)

it would be less informative. A missing TOC is an error condition in that it indicates a problem with the configuration/installation so I think that it is appropriate to show this in the error log to help the developer/packagers fix the problem. A correctly configured product will never show this error.

Perhaps the exception and message can be condensed into the message, e.g.

Error reading help table of contents file /"com.cg.hwarn/toc2.xml" (java.io.FileNotFoundException - skipping file)

Anything after the first line of stack trace is not useful to the developer because it's listing help code, rather than their code.
